awd_titl_txt: BTT EAGER:  Plant genome editing and engineering via novel nanotechnology-based systems
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a national and global need to develop crop plants that yield greater food, feed, fiber and bioenergy related products. At the same time there is a need to develop crops with an increased tolerance to abiotic and biotic stress and reduced impacts on the environment. Genetic engineering and genome editing are important tools used for the study and improvement of crop plants. However, current genetic engineering/editing systems do not work efficiently, or in some cases at all in several crop species/varieties. The inability to genetically engineer certain species of plants, hinders the progress that can be made with related crops. This project is aimed at developing a new system to genetically engineer/edit plants using ultra-small, biodegradable, synthetic particles (nanoparticles).  Development of such a system would enable more rapid advancement in crop genomics research and production of crops with enhanced traits and performance. In addition, the knowledge generated through this research may be utilized in the enhancement of other genome editing applications.  

Genome engineering/editing systems are critical tools for the advancement of plant functional genomics and epigenomics research, and for genomics-based crop improvement efforts.  Major limitations in current plant genome engineering/editing systems - such as genotype dependence, low and variable efficiencies, and/or inability to accomplish integration-free, germline editing have significantly impeded efficient, widespread utilization of these technologies for crop genomics research and genetic improvement applications. To overcome these limitations, and to increase the efficiency and breadth of plant genome editing a nanoparticle-based systems for introducing bioengineering molecular machinery into target cells capable of regenerating germline edited plants is being developed.  The specific aim of the research project is: to demonstrate nanoparticle-mediated delivery of Cas9/sgRNA ribonuleoprotein (RNP) complexes into target cells in a genotype-independent manner, and successful editing of target DNA sequences in plant cells/tissues, as well as regeneration of genome-edited plants. Novel, biodegradeable nanoparticle-based systems (nanocapsule and polyplex) are used to deliver RNPs into optimal plant cell/tissue targets to generate genome-edited plant cells and tissues from which germline edited plants can be recovered. Microscopic, visual and molecular assays will be conducted to determine genome editing success, location, frequency and inheritance. What is learned here can be applied not only to plant systems, but also in non-plant editing applications. Development of an efficient, genotype-independent nanoparticle-based plant gene editing system would have significant positive impact on genome engineering-based functional genomics research and crop improvement efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plant genetic engineering (transformation) and gene editing systems are critical tools to aid in studying how plant genes work, and for use in genetically improving crops. Current transformation and editing systems are limited, however, due to inefficiency, expense, difficult protocols, and inability to work on a wide array of plant varieties and species.  Development of systems in which nanoparticles can be used to carry DNA, RNA, and gene editing-related cargos (ribonucleoproteins, RNPs) into plant cells may be a way to overcome the above limitations. This research project focused on developing and testing new types of organic nanoparticles to deliver various kinds of genetic materials into plant cells that have intact cell walls and, through in vitro culture, have the ability to regenerate into transformed or gene-edited plants. Because plant cell walls and cell membranes allow only very tiny (nanometer-sized) particles to pass into the cell, novel nanoparticles were designed that could both protect and carry genetic cargos into cells yet remain under the size limit for cell penetration. Optimization of nanoparticle properties (such as particle shape, charge, outer/inner coat chemistries), led to successful delivery of DNA, RNA and RNPs into intact plant cells, and expression of the DNA/RNA gene sequences, and gene editing by the RNPs. Further modifications were made to increase efficiency of nanoparticle uptake into plant cells and increase the amount and types of cargos that could be transported. New knowledge on nanoparticle design and construction, plant cell biology, and plant genome engineering/editing was generated through this interdisciplinary research, and several diverse graduate students, postdoctoral research associates and undergraduate students were mentored and trained on this project. The nanoparticle-mediated transformation/editing systems developed through this research project can now be tested on an array of regenerable plant cell targets. System optimization will continue toward the goal of achieving variety and species-flexible, efficient plant transformation and editing, and regeneration of engineered plants that are capable of passing the transgenes/edits to progeny seed.  Establishment of such a system will greatly aid in advancing studies on plant gene structure, function, and control of plant traits, and in the development of genetically improved crops to meet current and future food, feed, fiber, and fuel needs in an agronomically and environmentally sustainable manner.


Last Modified: 03/15/2022
Modified by: Heidi F Kaeppler
